node.title: Formula for ConservedLangevin Noise?
node.bodyText:
I am not able to find the formula being used for ConservedLangevin Noise in the docs: ConservedLangevinNoise.
There is a formula given for the non-conserved Langevin noise in the docs: LangevinNoise
I don't see anything similar for Conservedlangevin noise.
Would appreciate some sources or references for the formula being used for Conserved Langevin noise. I don't have MOOSE installed and I am just trying to replicate a paper in a different software. So, I don't really know how to go through the code to find the formulation.

Hello
Please see the source for the kernel here
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/phase_field/src/kernels/ConservedLangevinNoise.C
As you can see in the docs for ConservedLangevinNoise, the noise comes from user objects. You can find the source for them here
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/tree/next/modules/phase_field/src/userobjects
Guillaume
Thank you!

node.title: Running out of RAM
node.bodyText:
Good afternoon, I am trying to run a 3D mesh (160x40x20 since I had problems with coarser meshes), however my program is almost instantly eating out all my RAM (256Gb available). Does MOOSE have a way to automatically throttle the usage of RAM? I am already throttling back the amount of cores I am using try try and slow things down. I do not have anything to show for it since my computer just dies without much notice.
If it helps i am running on Linux Rocky9.

Hello
When does it crash? the mesh is not that big. I think you may be using a non-scalable preconditioniner
Does the live print of the memory consumption tell you which part is consuming so much?
To reduce the memory cost you ll want to use less processes at first.
Using distributed meshes or cheaper preconditioning will let you add more processes
Guillaume
The application would usually crash during the adaptation of the mesh. Unfortunately I was not able to find the exact part, simply a correlation of the events.

If you turn off adaptivity it goes through?
I think there's an option in the mesh not to repartition. I wonder if the repartitioning is expensive memory wise (of course it helps later on, but there's a solve involved to compute it)

Yes removing the adptivity does allow it to run however the 320x80x40 is the largest mesh that can realistically be run. Idealy i was wondering if it was possible to add an option in moose to scale back/slow down as the limits get approached so that instead of crashing the desktop it simply slows itself down. Otherwise i can never create a finer mesh and let it run because it would crash.

How many rounds of adaptivity are you running? Maybe you are really running out of memory from adaptivity
and how many elements are getting refined? Can you limit that?

node.title: Dynamic Fracture Raccoon
node.bodyText:
HI all,
I am trying to simulate dynamic fracture using RACCOON.  I started out by adapting the tutorial files for static fractures and that was working well. As my end goal is to simulate acoustic emissions I am interested nodal vibrations from dynamic fracture. As a result I have adapted the boundary conditions and mesh from the brittle fracture example as well as included the dynamic tensor mechanics master action with the aim of replicating the setup shown in figure  6 of this paper: https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Huilong-Ren/publication/332063166_An_explicit_phase_field_method_for_brittle_dynamic_fracture/links/5ca47fa7458515f785203c36/An-explicit-phase-field-method-for-brittle-dynamic-fracture.pdf
I was hoping to see nodal vibrations in response to the material fracture but the displacement curve for the marked node below the fracture zone looks smooth despite some oscillations in the velocity and elastic strain. I have included the graphs below.
I am unsure if I am implementing the dynamics tensor mechanics master action correctly and I would be grateful If you could take a look at my input file. Could you confirm that RACCOON is compatible with the dynamic tensor mechanics kernels?
I have also done some preliminary research into other fracture modelling methods such as XFEM and Peridynamics. Am I correct in thinking that XFEM would not work for dynamic fracture as it assumes quasi-static crack growth, solving the equilibrium equations iteratively. I have seen Peridynamics being suggested for dynamic fracture. Would this be a better option and if so what is the best way of implementing this?
Thank you


d_elasticity.i:
E = 32e9
nu = 0.2
K = '${fparse E/3/(1-2*nu)}'
G = '${fparse E/2/(1+nu)}'

Gc = 3
l = 2e-5

[MultiApps]
  [fracture]
    type = TransientMultiApp
    input_files = d_fracture.i
    cli_args = 'Gc=${Gc};l=${l}'
    execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END'
  []
[]

[Transfers]
  [from_d]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    multi_app = fracture
    direction = from_multiapp
    variable = d
    source_variable = d
  []
  [to_psie_active]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    multi_app = fracture
    direction = to_multiapp
    variable = psie_active
    source_variable = psie_active
  []
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]



[Mesh]
  [top_half]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 500
    ny = 100
    ymin = 0
    ymax = 0.02
    xmin = 0
    xmax = 0.1
    boundary_id_offset = 0
    boundary_name_prefix = top_half
  []
  [top_stitch]
    type = BoundingBoxNodeSetGenerator
    input = top_half
    new_boundary = top_stitch
    bottom_left = '0.05 0 0'
    top_right = '0.1 0 0'
  []
  [bottom_half]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 500
    ny = 100
    ymin = -0.02
    ymax = 0
    xmin = 0
    xmax = 0.1
    boundary_id_offset = 5
    boundary_name_prefix = bottom_half
  []
  [bottom_stitch]
    type = BoundingBoxNodeSetGenerator
    input = bottom_half
    new_boundary = bottom_stitch
    bottom_left = '0.05 0 0'
    top_right = '0.1 0 0'
  []
  [stitch]
    type = StitchedMeshGenerator
    inputs = 'top_stitch bottom_stitch'
    stitch_boundaries_pairs = 'top_stitch bottom_stitch'
  []
  construct_side_list_from_node_list = true
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [fy]
  []
  [d]
  []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/DynamicMaster]
  [all]
    add_variables = true
    newmark_beta = 0.25
    newmark_gamma = 0.5
    strain = SMALL
    density = 2450
    generate_output = 'stress_yy strain_yy'
    mass_damping_coefficient = 0
    stiffness_damping_coefficient = 0
    hht_alpha = 0
    use_automatic_differentiation = true 
  []
[]


[Materials]
  [bulk]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'K G density'
    prop_values = '${K} ${G} 2450'
  []
  [degradation]
    type = PowerDegradationFunction
    f_name = g
    function = (1-d)^p*(1-eta)+eta
    phase_field = d
    parameter_names = 'p eta '
    parameter_values = '2 1e-6'
  []

  [elasticity]
    type = SmallDeformationIsotropicElasticity
    bulk_modulus = K
    shear_modulus = G
    phase_field = d
    degradation_function = g
    decomposition = NONE
    output_properties = 'elastic_strain psie_active'
    outputs = exodus
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeSmallDeformationStress
    elasticity_model = elasticity
    output_properties = 'stress'
    outputs = exodus
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [top_pull]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0 1'
    y = '1 1'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [top_y]
   type = Pressure
   variable = disp_y
   function = top_pull
   factor = -1e6
   boundary = top_half_top

   []
  [bottom_y]
   type = Pressure
   variable = disp_y
   function = -1e6
   boundary = bottom_half_bottom

   []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./smp]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient

  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist                 '
  automatic_scaling = true

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10

  dt = 7.578e-8
  end_time = 1.4e-4

  fixed_point_max_its = 20
  accept_on_max_fixed_point_iteration = true
  fixed_point_rel_tol = 1e-8
  fixed_point_abs_tol = 1e-10
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  print_linear_residuals = false
  []


d_fracture.i:
[Mesh]
  [top_half]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 500
    ny = 100
    ymin = 0
    ymax = 0.02
    xmin = 0
    xmax = 0.1
    boundary_id_offset = 0
    boundary_name_prefix = top_half
  []
  [top_stitch]
    type = BoundingBoxNodeSetGenerator
    input = top_half
    new_boundary = top_stitch
    bottom_left = '0.05 0 0'
    top_right = '0.1 0 0'
  []
  [bottom_half]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 500
    ny = 100
    ymin = -0.02
    ymax = 0
    xmin = 0
    xmax = 0.1
    boundary_id_offset = 5
    boundary_name_prefix = bottom_half
  []
  [bottom_stitch]
    type = BoundingBoxNodeSetGenerator
    input = bottom_half
    new_boundary = bottom_stitch
    bottom_left = '0.05 0 0'
    top_right = '0.1 0 0'
  []
  [stitch]
    type = StitchedMeshGenerator
    inputs = 'top_stitch bottom_stitch'
    stitch_boundaries_pairs = 'top_stitch bottom_stitch'
  []
  construct_side_list_from_node_list = true
[]

[Variables]
  [d]
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [bounds_dummy]
  []
  [psie_active]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[Bounds]
  [irreversibility]
    type = VariableOldValueBoundsAux
    variable = bounds_dummy
    bounded_variable = d
    bound_type = lower
  []
  [upper]
    type = ConstantBoundsAux
    variable = bounds_dummy
    bounded_variable = d
    bound_type = upper
    bound_value = 1
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diff]
    type = ADPFFDiffusion
    variable = d
    fracture_toughness = Gc
    regularization_length = l
    normalization_constant = c0
  []
  [source]
    type = ADPFFSource
    variable = d
    free_energy = psi
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [fracture_properties]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'Gc l'
    prop_values = '${Gc} ${l}'
  []
  [degradation]
    type = PowerDegradationFunction
    f_name = g
    function = (1-d)^p*(1-eta)+eta
    phase_field = d
    parameter_names = 'p eta '
    parameter_values = '2 1e-6'
  []
  [crack_geometric]
    type = CrackGeometricFunction
    f_name = alpha
    function = 'd^2'
    phase_field = d
  []
  [psi]
    type = ADDerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = psi
    function = 'alpha*Gc/c0/l+g*psie_active'
    args = 'd psie_active'
    material_property_names = 'alpha(d) g(d) Gc c0 l'
    derivative_order = 1
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient

  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package -snes_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist                  vinewtonrsls'
  automatic_scaling = true

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
[]

[Outputs]
  print_linear_residuals = false
[]
@hugary1995 @BoZeng1997

node.title: How is integration in axi-symmetric coordinates implemented?
node.bodyText:
Hi, I am writing some kernels generalized to cylindrical coordinate for axi-symmetric cases. Currently, the extra works I have done compared to simulation in cartesian coordinate include:

Set "coord_type = RZ" in mesh module.
Write integrand (both residual and jacobian) specialized for cylindrical coordinate. For example, there is an extra term u_r / r in velocity divergence.
However, as I understand, the integrand should be multiplied by r when applying integration. I want to confirm this is automatically implemented in MOOSE. May you check if I missed anything?

Hello


is correct


Yes we automatically do that (and the 2pi factor too) when you specify coord_type of RZ
You are correct that you need to implement the extra term u_r / r


Guillaume

node.title: build error
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts
I am trying to install moose for HPC. at first I created conda moose environment for LInux users by following commands of the link: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html then I followed the instructions are given for those operating on an HPC cluster: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html. but when I am trying to update and rebuild the libmesh.sh highlited here

it is showing following errors:
PETSc submodule will be used. PETSc submodule is our default solver.
IMPORTANT: If you did not run the update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh script yet, please run it before building libMesh
---------------------------------------------
----------- Configuring libMesh -------------
---------------------------------------------
checking build system type... x86_64-pc-linux-gnu
checking host system type... x86_64-pc-linux-gnu
checking target system type... x86_64-pc-linux-gnu
checking for a BSD-compatible install... /home/mdewan/projects/moose/scripts/../libmesh/build-aux/install-sh -C

checking whether make sets $(MAKE)... yes

checking whether GID '1047' is supported by ustar format... yes

checking whether make supports nested variables... (cached) yes
checking whether to enable maintainer-specific portions of Makefiles... no
checking for src/base/libmesh.C... no
<<< Configuring build directory for VPATH build >>>
checking for perl... /usr/bin/perl
note: MPI library path not given...
trying prefix=/usr/lib64/compat-openmpi16
note: MPI library path not given...
trying prefix=/usr/lib64/compat-openmpi16
checking whether make supports the include directive... yes (GNU style)
checking whether the C compiler works... no
configure: error: in `/home/mdewan/projects/moose/libmesh/build':
configure: error: C compiler cannot create executables
See `config.log' for more details
Running make -j 6...
make: *** No targets specified and no makefile found.  Stop.

Could you please help me?

Hello
Please run the diagnostics script in moose/scripts
Seems the compiler being found is not working:
checking whether the C compiler works... no

Guillaume

Dear GiudGiud
It is showing following information:
System Arch: LSB Version: :core-4.1-amd64:core-4.1-noarch:cxx-4.1-amd64:cxx-4.1-noarch:desktop-4.1-amd64:desktop-4.1-noarch:languages-4.1-amd64:languages-4.1-noarch:printing-4.1-amd64:printing-4.1-noarch Distributor ID: CentOS Description: CentOS Linux release 7.9.2009 (Core) Release: 7.9.2009 Codename: Core
MOOSE Package Version: Custom Build
CPU Count: 16
Memory Free: 2250.941 MB
$CC not set
MPICC WRAPPER NOT FOUND
Python:
/home/mdewan/miniforge/bin/python
Python 3.10.13
MODULES:
Currently Loaded Modules:

slurm/slurm/19.05.8   2) GCCcore/10.3.0   3) zlib/1.2.11-GCCcore-10.3.0   4) binutils/2.36.1-GCCcore-10.3.0   5) GCC/10.3.0   6) mpi/compat-openmpi16-x86_64

You need to find mpicc, mpif90 and mpicxx on your system.
Once you have found those (likely coming from 6) mpi/compat-openmpi16-x86_64) you need to set:
export PATH=<path to mpicc etc>:${PATH}
export CC=mpicc
export CXX=mpicxx
export F90=mpif90
You'll also most likely need to rebuild PETSc as a result. It seems PETSc may have found some other compiler (I am assuming it finished since we're talking about update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh

Dear GiudGiud
I got the location of mpicc, mpif90 and mpicxx on my system.
/home/mdewan/miniforge/envs/moose/bin
But I didn't understand this line "Once you have found those (likely coming from 6) mpi/compat-openmpi16-x86_64) you need to set:"
because I didn't find " mpi/compat-openmpi16-x86_64" in this location. How can I set
export PATH=:${PATH}
export CC=mpicc
export CXX=mpicxx
export F90=mpif90

these are environment variables. You set or modify them using export
So you want to use miniforge to build? You have a mpi module (openmpi) loaded. you have to choose. On a HPC infrastructure, you should likely use the MPI module
Yes, this miniforge was automatically built up during conda environment creation

this is fine if you want to install this way but you cannot do that:

at first I created conda moose environment for LInux users by following commands of the link: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html then I followed the instructions are given for those operating on an HPC cluster: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html.

you have to pick one way and stick to it

I have set the following environment and tried to rebuild the  PETSc, libMesh, and WASP.
export PATH=<path to mpicc etc>:${PATH}
export CC=mpicc
export CXX=mpicxx
export F90=mpif90


Still it is showing the following error: can not find -ludev etc.

node.title: 1D wave propagation
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I ran a case, and didnt get the expected results. So, I tried to run a very simple case: 1D wave propagation; transient.
The case is the following: 1D bar, Length 1m, E=200GPA, fixed on the left, loaded on the right.
#=============-->
I applied a sinosoidal load F(t) = 0.01sin(2pi*t), for 0<t<0.5, and ran the simulation for 1s in 100 steps.
My problem is the following:
I open results in paraview, select the end point (the loaded one) and a point nead the middle of the bar. I expected a wave traveling from the left to the right, i.e. the midpoint should exhibit the same behavior as the loaded point, but with time-delay. Instead, the two points appear to be synced.
Below is the code of my case. Initially, I used TensorMechanics/Master, and then DynamicsMaster, but no change:
[GlobalParams]
    displacements = disp_x
[]

[Mesh]
    [bar]
        type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
        dim = 1
        xmax = 1
        nx = 100
    []
[]

[Materials]
    [elasticity]
        type = ADComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
        youngs_modulus = 200e9
        poissons_ratio = 0.3
    []

    [stress]
        type = ADComputeLinearElasticStress
    []

    [dens]
        type = ADDensity
        density = 6800
    []
[]

[BCs]
    [fix_left]
        type = ADDirichletBC
        variable = disp_x
        value = 0
        boundary = left
    []
[]

[DiracKernels]
    [load]
        type = FunctionDiracSource
        function = load
        variable = disp_x
        point = '1 0 0'
    []
[]

[Functions]
    [load]
      type = ParsedFunction
      expression = 'if(t<0.5,0.01*sin(2*pi*t), 0)'
    []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/DynamicMaster]
    [all]
        add_variables = true
        strain = SMALL
        use_automatic_differentiation = true
    []
[]

[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    num_steps = 100
    end_time = 1
[]

[Outputs]
    exodus = true
[]

The displacement  I get (for the midpoint) is shown in the figure:

It shouldnt start moving at t=0.
What am I doing wrong? Must something very stuping that I am missing here! :(

Hello
I think when you are NOT using dynamics, this is very normal. The regular Master tensor mechanics action is quasi-static, so the system always reaches equilibrium and that kind of perturbation would be instantaneous
For dynamics, I think:

either your system is really rigid or your time steps are too big to see the delay
Can you try refining the time steps?

Guillaume
Changing to DynamicMaster and reducing the stiffness did the job. Thanks!

node.title: Evaluate a material property/aux variable at arbitrary location using interpolation
node.bodyText: Hi all, I would like to do something similar as in DiscreteNucleation, but the nuclei location is independent of quadrature points, the nucleation is energy-based by evaluating the shear strain energy density involving stress tensor. I would like to get stress tensor values at those locations using interpolation. I wonder if there is an easy way to achieve it, thanks!

Hello
The stress tensor is a tensor material property right?
Is that the only quantity you want to evaluate at an arbitrary point?

yes I think so, the formula is as follows:
$$\phi = \frac{1}{2G} \sigma_{ij}'(x^k) \sigma_{ij}'(x^k), \sigma_{ij}'= \sigma_{ij} - \frac{1}{3} \sigma_{kk} \delta_{ij}$$
$x^k$ is the location of the nuclei

what kind of interpolation do you want?
Do you think you could compute it from the location of the quadrature points and the values at those quadrature points?

So the energy of the nuclei is the criterion to nucleate the nuclei ($\phi > \phi_c = const$), I prefer not to restrict the placement of nuclei by the quadrature point locations. If I use higher-order elements for the field, given the qp values within the element, it should be able to compute the value at a point within this element by interpolation.
I have the implementation in FENICS before, which handles this quite easily: _stress->eval(point_value,point_locs);, I'm not sure if MOOSE has something similar.

If you were using a functor material property instead of a regular material property, we have exactly these kind of evaluations at arbirtrary point implemented.

If I use higher-order elements for the field

the field of stress tensors, which FE family and order is it supposed to be? If any
Thanks @GiudGiud. I think the stress field can be FIRST MONOMINAL , not high-order for now.

I would project it onto a few auxiliary variables of type FIRST MONOMIAL for each component then.
Once you have that done, you can evaluate them at an arbitrary location using the Functor APIs:
see the ElemPointArg here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Functors/index.html
Thanks @GiudGiud, I would give it a try.

node.title: Heat exchanger
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
For my master thesis I need to add a coaxial heat exchanger inside my geological model which was done using GOLEM.

I need to investigate heat storage in earth for that I need circulate water inside the tubes. But I am fairly new to MOOSE. Do you know whether I can do it inside MOOSE without using any modules or do I need a particular module to do so. Also I need the temperature of water upon entrance to the outer pipe where it is being injected to be constant. How can I do this? I appreciate your advice.
Best regards,
@1runer @cpgr can you please @saturngreen67 to some porous flow + thermal hydraulics modules examples?

Hi @saturngreen67
this sounds like an interesting application and quite extensive for a standard master thesis.
GOLEM is a MOOSE-based application that mainly simplifies what is possible with MOOSE PorousFlow module
The difficulty for you is that in geothermal applications the borehole is mostly simplified including a 1D line (GOLEM) or PolyLineSink (PorousFlow). Therefore it is impossible to represent the internal structure of a coaxial well within.
You would have different options:

Explicit meshing of the coaxial hole with 3D elements and various blocks that assign the material properties for the inner or outer loop. This results in a large number of elements and a fairly fine meshing.
Keeping the GOLEM model and using the MultiApp system. Calculating the wellbore flow  and internal heat exchange in a sub-app like Thermal hydraulics and connecting it just in the bottom-most point of your borehole with the reservoir (exchange of temperature and pressure). A comparable example connecting a fracture via MultiApp is explained HERE

I don't know of any example connecting PorousFlow and Thermal hydraulics.
@GiudGiud Probably something similar with Navier-Stokes and Thermal hydraulics?
Also have a look at this Discussion. Even not fully solved, he uses the MultiApp approach for something similar.
Thank you very much for your prompt response. I will try your suggestions and will get back to you.

@1runer Thank you for your last reply. I had a meeting with my supervisor and she told me that I should put a 2D heat exchanger inside my 3D GOLEM model. Do you have any ideas on how it can be implemented or where I should begin?
You can use the same approach (multiapp) with a 2D heat exchanger.

What is the advantage of a 2D heat exchanger in a 3D domain?
I'm not aware how you properly scale the variables for the missing 3rd dimension.
3D in 3D could be an option, but you will create a large number of elements with high computational expense.
I recommend using either MultiApp ( as @GiudGiud ) suggested or defining a conceptual model where you can represent it as 1D line.
@saturngreen67 keep us updated about the approach to solve your problem.

I imagine the 2D shape is closer to the real shape of the exchanger (thin) than the 1D shape.
Intensive variables (temperature, pressure) would not need to be scaled. @1runer is right that for extensive variables (mass flow, energy) you will need to make sure the approach is conservative
@1runer @GiudGiud Thank you both, I will try my options and keep you informed of my final approach

node.title: Questions on build documentation on Mastodon
node.bodyText:
Hi all, I have a maybe simple question about building documentation on Mastodon, I fork the Mastodon on my local app, with moose and blackbear placed aside, I'm able to build the executable. Then when I run "./moosedocs.py" returns error: modules are not found for "MooseDocs" and "mooseutils".
I try to change the python interpreter to use minforge/moose related ones, but it's not helping. I know the "MooseDocs" dir is under "moose/python", what should I do to link it to Mastodon? Thanks!

You should be able to add the python folder within moose to your PYTHONPATH. Much like your system PATH, it will check the directories placed there first for any modules. See the command you need to enter into your terminal below to set that before running moosedocs again (also make sure your moose environment is activated, as normal). Make sure you replace the sample path I use below with your actual path to moose/python!
export PYTHONPATH=/Users/username/projects/mastodon/moose/python

This will be unset whenever you close your Terminal, so you'll need to re-add it if you want to use it again.

Thanks @cticenhour. I just find it a bit weird that after I git clone the mastodon repo, the "moose" and "blackbear" folders are empty, so I git clone both as well to place alongside with "mastodon" in the same folder. After I did when you suggest above, it pops up error about not finding "mastodon/moose/large_media", which makes sense because it's empty. How should I deal with it? Thanks again.

Hello
Use the git submodule init and git submodule update commands to get these folders to be filled
For large_media, it s a submodule of moose, which is itself a submodule of mastodon. You can recursively init and update submodules with git submodule init moose --recursive iirc
Thanks @GiudGiud. it works fine now!

node.title: Why can't I use TimeFunctionComponentControl in HeatTransferFromHeatFlux1Phase?
node.bodyText:
@joshuahansel @GiudGiud Hello. I found that I couldn't use TimeFunctionComponentControl in HeatTransferFromHeatFlux1Phase.
I set the input file like:
  [FLOWSC1_POWER]
    type = HeatTransferFromHeatFlux1Phase
    flow_channel = core_chan1
    q_wall = 0
    P_hf = ${fparse pi*rod_diameter/2.0}
  [../]
  [set_power1_value]
    type = TimeFunctionComponentControl
    component = FLOWSC1_POWER
    parameter = q_wall
    function = PowerTran
  [../]

And in terminal:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "set_power1_value", of type "TimeFunctionComponentControl".
The desired parameter 'component/FLOWSC1_POWER/Hw' was not located for the 'set_power1_value' object, it either does not exist or has not been declared as controllable.

Is there anything wrong with my setting?
Ethan

That component/parameter is currently incompatible with TimeFunctionComponentControl. Usually we make component parameters like this to be Real parameters (which we can make controllable), but this one is a FunctionName parameter. So you can just use your function directly:
q_wall = PowerTran

Just thinking out loud, I think we should make these parameters into FunctionName parameters because you can always just supply a ConstantFunction whose value parameter is controllable.
I got it. Thank you!
Oh wait, the PowerTran is a PiecewiseLinear function which is time-dependent. If I use q_wall = PowerTran directly, how should I express a time-dependent function using PiecewiseLinear?
Oh I see, the x corresponds to time by default.
